articles.headline: Emerging Markets Lose Their Luster as Crises Mount
articles.snippet: Once seen as a necessity in portfolios, investments in countries like Brazil and Russia are being reassessed because of messy politics and flagging economies.
articles.abstract: Once seen as a necessity in portfolios, investments in countries like Brazil and Russia are being reassessed because of messy politics and flagging economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Russia, it’s assassinations and war. In Brazil, a corruption scandal may derail the economy. And in Turkey, the president is attacking the country’s senior central banker.

articles.headline: In Tidjane Thiam, Credit Suisse Gets Risk Expertise
articles.snippet: Mr. Thiam was chosen to lead a company that has done poorly after emerging from a scandal.
articles.abstract: Mr. Thiam was chosen to lead a company that has done poorly after emerging from a scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When the chief executive of the British insurer Prudential prepared for his company’s 2010 annual meeting, he was told, only partly in jest, that he should bring along two suits.

articles.headline: ‘Blurred Lines’ Infringed on Marvin Gaye Copyright, Jury Rules
articles.snippet: The jury found that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams, who share a songwriting credit on the song, had committed copyright infringement, and it awarded more than $7.3 million to Mr. Gaye’s family.
articles.abstract: The jury found that Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams, who share a songwriting credit on the song, had committed copyright infringement, and it awarded more than $7.3 million to Mr. Gaye’s family.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the last year and a half, the music industry has been gripped by a lawsuit over whether Robin Thicke’s 2013 hit “Blurred Lines” was merely reminiscent of a song by Marvin Gaye, or had crossed the line into plagiarism.
articles.byline: By Ben Sisario and Noah Smith

articles.headline: Gender Gap in Education Cuts Both Ways
articles.snippet: A report from the O.E.C.D. revives an old debate about girls’ math abilities, while it raises questions about boys’ overall educational achievements.
articles.abstract: A report from the O.E.C.D. revives an old debate about girls’ math abilities, while it raises questions about boys’ overall educational achievements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why do the best-educated girls do worse at math than top-educated boys?

articles.headline: Ferguson City Manager Cited in Justice Department Report Resigns
articles.snippet: A federal report said the manager, John Shaw, was responsible for much of the questionable conduct by the police and the courts in Ferguson, Mo.
articles.abstract: A federal report said the manager, John Shaw, was responsible for much of the questionable conduct by the police and the courts in Ferguson, Mo.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The city manager of Ferguson, whom a Department of Justice report blamed for overseeing the financially driven policies that led to widespread discrimination and questionable conduct by the police and the courts here, has agreed to resign. The announcement came during a City Council meeting on Tuesday, about a week after the scathing Justice Department report was released.

articles.headline: For Chinese Economy, Strengths Are Now Weaknesses
articles.snippet: Traditional drivers of growth — like steel making and real estate — are now among the biggest threats to China’s economy, slowing faster than the market can be transformed.
articles.abstract: Traditional drivers of growth — like steel making and real estate — are now among the biggest threats to China’s economy, slowing faster than the market can be transformed.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s exports of steel are soaring. But that is not a good sign for the economy.

articles.headline: Unsettled at Home, Veterans Volunteer to Fight ISIS
articles.snippet: A small number of Americans have offered to take up arms against the Islamic State, working with local militias in Iraq and Syria.
articles.abstract: A small number of Americans have offered to take up arms against the Islamic State, working with local militias in Iraq and Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Last fall, Patrick Maxwell, a 29-year-old Iraq war veteran now selling real estate in this bustling city, saw something in news footage of Islamic fighters in Iraq that he never saw as an infantry Marine there: the enemy.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Thomas James Brennan
